facts.text: High Court passed order dated 9th March, 2007 setting aside State Administrative Tribunal order in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent it held V. Jagannadha Rao judgment prospective.

anchor.surface_text: 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrative Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: High Court dismissed review petition on 3rd November, 2010 filed by appellants against the order dated 9th March, 2007.

anchor.surface_text: An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants against the said order has also been assailed.

facts.text: Presidential Order issued on 18th October, 1975 under Article 371-D of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: the Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution was aimed at providing equitable opportunities and facilities to the people belonging to different parts of the State in the matter of public employment, education etc.

facts.text: GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made UDCs of Labour Department and Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspector of Labour and Assistant Inspector of Factories.

anchor.surface_text: a challenge mounted by the Ministerial employees of the Labour Department against GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 whereunder UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

facts.text: Full Bench of Tribunal declared impugned Rules violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order.

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of Tribunal before whom the challenge came up for consideration declared that the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be considered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

facts.text: Supreme Court in V. Jagannadha Rao held Special Rules violative of Presidential Order and overruled Sadanandam and Satyanarayana Rao cases.

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5(1) thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers. ... Overruling the decisions rendered by this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr. v. V. Sadanandam and Ors. 1989 Supp. (1) SCC 574, and in Govt. Of A.P. and Anr. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao Dead by Lrs. And Ors.  2000  4 SCC 262

facts.text: G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 provided Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers in Head Offices eligible for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training (Ser. IV) Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996. These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Employees approached Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal aggrieved by G.O.Ms as post of Assistant Labour Officer is zonal post.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the G.O.Ms. some of the employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal for redressal. Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel.

facts.text: Tribunal partly allowed petitions by order dated 7th March, 2003 striking down G.O.M. No.14 and amendment prospectively, saving actions till 7th November, 2001.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were partly allowed by the Tribunal in terms of its order dated 7th March, 2003 and G.O.M. No.14, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 struck down as unconstitutional to the extent the same provided a channel for Senior Assistant and Senior Stenographer in Andhra Pradesh Ministerial Service working in the Head Offices of Labour Department and those in Factories and Boiler Departments ... The Tribunal also struck down related provisions ... with a direction that the respondents shall not give effect to the said provisions. Having said that the Tribunal directed that the striking down of the impugned O.Ms. would only be prospective and that any action taken in compliance with the said Rules till 7th November, 2001 shall not be disturbed nor any employee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case supra reverted.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal judgment to extent saving promotions.

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved employees, who had approached the Tribunal having succeeded but only in part, filed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 whereby they challenged the judgment of the Tribunal to the extent it saved the promotions already made on the basis of the impugned G.O.Ms.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 filed against Tribunal judgment striking down G.O.Ms.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 was also filed against the very same judgment by some of the employees who felt aggrieved by the view taken by the Tribunal that the impugned G.O.Ms. were in violation of the Presidential Order hence unconstitutional.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed WP 6163 and 6068 of 2004, dismissed WP 16890 of 2006 on 9th March, 2007 holding prospective overruling only by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court. The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010 contending they were necessary parties not impleaded.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these appeals are employees who were not arrayed as parties to the writ petition filed before the High Court. Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made.

facts.text: High Court rejected review contention and dismissed on 3rd November, 2010.

anchor.surface_text: That contention was, however, rejected by the High Court on the ground that the order passed by the Tribunal ought to have been challenged in a separate and independent writ petition by anyone aggrieved by the same. The review petitions were, accordingly, dismissed and the prayer for grant of leave to appeal to this Court rejected.

facts.text: OA in V. Jagannadha Rao filed in 1987, Tribunal order dated 17th April, 1995, SC judgment 7th November, 2001.

anchor.surface_text: In Jagannadha Raos case supra , the petitions were filed in the year 1987. The State Administrative Tribunal had declared the rule providing for inter-department transfer by promotion to be bad by its order dated 17th April, 1995. The legal position eventually came to be settled by the decision of this Court in the case on 7th November, 2001.

facts.text: Present OAs filed before Tribunal in 1997, Tribunal order 27th March, 2003.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions in the present case were filed before the State Administrative Tribunal in the year 1997. The Tribunal had on the authority of the judgment aforementioned struck down the rules providing for ex-cadre zone promotions by its order dated 27th March, 2003, but saved the promotions already made.

facts.text: Promotions made before 7th November, 2001 continued for nearly ten years till review dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Promotions made before the pronouncement of the order in Jagannadha Raos case supra i.e. before 7th November, 2001 have, thus, continued for nearly ten years till the review petition filed by the petitioners was dismissed and the matter brought up before this Court.

facts.text: State Administrative Tribunal declared rule bad by order dated 17th April, 1995 in Jagannadha Rao context.

anchor.surface_text: The State Administrative Tribunal had declared the rule providing for inter-department transfer by promotion to be bad by its order dated 17th April, 1995.

facts.text: Appellants are employees promoted under impugned GOMs, not parties to writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these appeals are employees who were not arrayed as parties to the writ petition filed before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: State Administrative Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997

anchor.surface_text: since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel.

facts.text: Tribunal struck down provisions providing for consideration of employees from Factories and Boilers Units for promotion in Labour Unit.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal rightly held the provision to the extent it provides for consideration of employees of the Factories and Boilers Units to be invalid, for the purpose of promotion to the higher post in the Labour Unit

facts.text: Supreme Court pronounced judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao on 7th November, 2001.

anchor.surface_text: till 7th November, 2001 shall not be disturbed nor any employee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case supra

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5 1  thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers. This Court further held that while para 5 2  authorised the State Government to make provisions for transfer in certain specified circumstances, yet the term transfer could not be enlarged in its amplitude so as to include promotional aspects.

holdings.text: The G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 are unconstitutional to the extent they provide for appointment by transfer of Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers from Head Offices and Factories/Boilers Departments to Assistant Labour Officer posts, being violative of paras 3(3) and 5(1) of the Presidential Order.

anchor.surface_text: Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel. Inclusion of other categories from outside the zone in the feeding channel for purposes of promotion or appointment by transfer was offensive to paras 3 3  and 5 1  of the Andhra Pradesh Public Employment  Organisation of Local Cards and Regulation of Direct Recruitment  Order, 1975

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying V. Jagannadha Rao precedent where similar rules held violative of Presidential Order para 5 as local cadre is unit for promotions; transfer excludes promotion per para 5(1)/(2) distinction; Art 371D(10) supremacy.

holdings.text: The doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other courts including High Courts under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court. The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Predominant legal opinion from SC precedents limits doctrine to SC; unnecessary to decide expressly for HC as SC invokes independently.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court invokes the doctrine of prospective overruling to save promotions made under the impugned G.O.Ms. prior to 7th November, 2001, making the declaration of invalidity prospective thereafter.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Arts 32/142 for complete justice; law in flux till VJ; 10 years continuation; non-impleadment of appointees; reversion injustice and cascading effect; analogous to Kailash Chand Sharma.

holdings.text: The appellants were not necessary parties to the writ petitions before the High Court; aggrieved employees must file separate independent writ petitions; non-impleadment does not vitiate the judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made. [...] That contention was, however, rejected by the High Court on the ground that the order passed by the Tribunal ought to have been challenged in a separate and independent writ petition by anyone aggrieved by the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural requirement for separate challenge; non-parties protected anyway via prospective overruling as in Kailash Chand.

holdings.text: The judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao does not preclude invocation of prospective overruling in this case as it concerned different G.O.Ms. (No.72/117 vs. No.14/22).

anchor.surface_text: Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.72 and 117 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer [...] may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules [...] were different [...].

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinction based on different rules/G.O.Ms despite similar legal issue.

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

outcome.relief_summary: Doctrine of prospective overruling invoked; past promotions under impugned G.O.Ms. prior to V. Jagannadha Rao judgment protected from disturbance or reversion
directions: Do not disturb promotions made before 7th November 2001 on basis of pre-existing legal position
No reversion of promoted employees to parent cadre
Balance equity to prevent miscarriage of justice

anchor.surface_text: Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel. Inclusion of other categories from outside the zone in the feeding channel for purposes of promotion or appointment by transfer was offensive to paras 3 3  and 5 1  of the Andhra Pradesh Public Employment  Organisation of Local Cards and Regulation of Direct Recruitment  Order, 1975

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court. The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made. [...] That contention was, however, rejected by the High Court on the ground that the order passed by the Tribunal ought to have been challenged in a separate and independent writ petition by anyone aggrieved by the same.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.
